block.p: Seventy years after it was built in Midtown Manhattan as the tallest building in the world (a title it held only briefly), the 77-story Art Deco masterpiece known as the Chrysler Building may get a chance to reclaim proper title to its name. The skyscraper was built by Walter P. Chrysler, founder of the Chrysler Corporation, who once had offices and a private dining room there. But after he died in 1940 the company's use of the building fell off and it was sold. Now, DaimlerChrysler A.G., the predominantly German-managed company into which the Chrysler Corporation was merged in 1988, said it was hoping to rent and renovate space in the building as a ''virtual headquarters'' where its board would meet and investor and public relations staffs would work.

Seventy years after it was built in Midtown Manhattan as the tallest building in the world (a title it held only briefly), the 77-story Art Deco masterpiece known as the Chrysler Building may get a chance to reclaim proper title to its name. The skyscraper was built by Walter P. Chrysler, founder of the Chrysler Corporation, who once had offices and a private dining room there. But after he died in 1940 the company's use of the building fell off and it was sold. Now, DaimlerChrysler A.G., the predominantly German-managed company into which the Chrysler Corporation was merged in 1988, said it was hoping to rent and renovate space in the building as a ''virtual headquarters'' where its board would meet and investor and public relations staffs would work.
